ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: all topics on general equilibrium!

We spent this class building up economic models, from simple linear production economies to complex financial markets. I think this class helped me understand the motive for each addition we add to our model, as well as providing a link to understanding our economy at large. It also helped me improve on my arithmetic skills, which had long depleted since high school. :>
HIstorical development and theoretical underpinnings of Modern General Equilibrium theory
We learned how to conceive and apply general equilibrium models to multiple real-world scenarios
This was one of the most interesting, thought provoking, and insightful economics courses Ive taken at Yale. It teaches a lot about how different policies affect the overall economy.
Excellent course. Lives up to the history of the GE course at Yale. John G is an excellent lecturer and the course is impeccably put together.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: John G is incredibly knowledgeable and paved the way for lots of this research in the leverage cycle and credit card equilibrium. this is a more theoretical approach to finance concepts that are very insightful
Weaknesses: psets due monday
I think it might be more helpful to have slides to teach the course, especially when solving questions, because copying matrices or equations take a lot of time and can be hard to follow.
Strengths: Interesting subject matter, well structured

The lecture notes are incredibly detailed and Prof. Geanakoplos is so knowledgeable in the field. In particular, he makes a concerted effort to make marginalized students in his class feel included by highlighting the successes of past marginalized students and using different pronouns in example problems. The one thing I wish is that there were slides to follow along in class - I could get a little lost between the lecture notes and writing on the chalk board.
Interesting material. Problems sets and exams were too algorithmic and repetitive.

Professor Geanakoplos is one of the most passionate and engaging teachers Ive had at Yale, and he truly cares about making sure his students are learning and asking questions. However, sometimes he is too smart and it will take multiple questions and explanations for the knowledge to catch on with his students.

Lecture notes are comprehensive and clear. John has thought clearly about how the narrative of course comes together. The teaching assistant support is also excellent and integrate to the course working (sections often important to review the material).

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes- was interesting to learn about general equilibrium

Yes. We covered a wide range of interesting material that I really came to understand well. Professor Geanakoplos is an engaging lecturer (though his lecturing style takes some getting used to) and a really nice guy. Much more rigorous than other economics classes, though I wish we had spent a bit more time presenting the proofs (especially the proof of existence of GE) in lecture. Doable for someone without much economics background.
I definitely recommend the course! The professor is very personable and engaging. The contents of this course is also approachable and interesting. Having good computational skills is a plus.
Yes, good for those interested in mathematical finance!
To anyone who enjoyed econ 121/125 or seeks a good applied math course
Yes, if you are interested in economics, economic history, and potentially grad school.
Yes, important to anyone considering serious economics study and to getting the mathematical intuitions of economics.
1000% absolutely
